snippet: JPMorgan Chase fought for the ability for banks to make big bets in their portfolios, including some of the types of trading that led to the $2 billion loss now rocking the bank.
abstract: Executives and lobbyists representing JPMorgan Chase pressed hard to establish a loophole in the the new financial regulatory law that would enable banks to make big bets in their portfolios; loophole, known as portfolio hedging, allowed the continuance of the types of trades that eventually resulted in the bank's $2 billion loss.

byline.contributor: Annie Lowrey contributed reporting from Washington and Ben Protess from Chicago.
